title: Elastic Collaborative Edge Intelligence for UAVs
content:
TargetIEEE ComSoc
Manuscript Submission Deadline: 15 December 2022
Publication Date: July 2023

Maximum number of pages: SEVEN(7)
Font: Times New Roman, 12-pt font size
20-pica column width
Not exceed 5500 words in total; inclusive of title, authorsâ€™ names/info, abstract, body (introduction to conclusion), figures, tables, captions, footnotes, acknowledgements, references, authorsâ€™ bios, etc. (everything)
Authorsâ€™ bios are not to exceed 150 words each

Parts to be completedAbstract                                        (1/2 page)
I. Introduction                                (  1  page)
IV. Performance Evaluation        (  1  page)
VI. Conclusion                                (1/2 page)
Writing DesignAbstract
I. Introduction
An army of applications on UAVs rely on deep learning (computing intensive, no military application) , ğŸ‘‡
UAVs usually have limited computing, memory and power resource ğŸ‘‡
Many works have paid attention to leverage the external powerful servers such as cloud and edge to reduce the burden of  resource-constrained end devices ( i.e., Cloud-Device CoEI, Edge-Device CoEI, Cloud-Edge-Device CoEI, Device-Device CoEI). ğŸ‘‡
Limitation for three conventional CoEI paradigms: communication link between UAVs and remote cloud server or ground edge is fluctuant, air-to-air links in a UAV swarm are unreliable and UAVs may breakdown for hardware/software errors. ğŸ‘‡
This article presents E-CoEI( Elastic Collaborative Edge Intelligence), a brand new architecture which enables a UAV swarm to collaboratively perform a DNN inference task in an on-demand and flexible manner.ğŸ‘‡
The main contributions of this  work:
(1) Propose a new CoEI framework, which could well adapt to UAV swarms with high dynamics;
(2) We construct a CoEI system and conduct a proof-of concept evaluation on E-CoEI framework, the results show that our proposed architecture is feasible and effective for Device-Device CoEI, even if the communication links and node conditions are unreliable;
(3) We point  out the main technical challenges in the E-CoEI framework, as well as potential research directions based on E-CoEI for future study.
IV. Performance Evaluation
To evaluate the performance of the proposed E-CoEI framework, we designed a proof-of-concept system. We first measured the average inference frame rate under different number of devices to reveal the influence of worker numbers to a CoEI system. Subsequently, we simulated an unstable situation in which a workerâ€™s connection was not available to evaluate feasible and effective of proposed E-CoEI system.
Introduce the experimental setup
Device: Jetson Nano (Master), Jetson TX2(Worker #1),  Jetson Nano(Worker #2),  Jetson Nano(Worker #3), ad-hoc module etc.

 


System components: Master and Workers
Communication Manner
Model: Faster R-CNN
Source: A video with a people and  bike
A.  Impacts of the number of workers
The average frame rate of collaborative inference vary from different number of workers. Using more inference node usually leads to higher frame rate (i.e., higher inference speed). 

 


B. Performance of proposed E-CoEI architecture
The system has the ability to cope with fluctuation in node connections.

 


VI. Conclusion
This article introduced E-CoEI, an invulnerable distributed COEI architecture focus on unstable A2A communication links and UAVs software/hardware breakdown. The preliminary evaluation over the self-built airborne embedded system demonstrated the effectiveness and feasibility of our proposed E-CoEI framework. There still lies a couple of technical challenges to realize its broad vision, such as UAV swarm status discovery, inference task distribution, etc. At the same time, there are promising research directions including UAV swarm management, network protocols design, multiple collaborative inference flows scheduling, dedicated DNN structure design, etc.

                FLOPs based
                [1]Neurosurgeon[2]ÂµLayer[3]PALEO
                Light-weight and easy to train.

                Blackbox ML model
                [4]nn-Meter[5]BRP-NAS[6]TVM[7]Learned TPU Cost ...[13]HELP[14]Reducing energy consumption...[15]Generalized Latency Performance ...[16]NNLQP[17]Predicting Latency of ...
                The prediction accuracy is high.

                Consider hardware characteristic
                [3]PALEO[8]CoDL[9]FBNet[15]Generalized Latency Performance ...
                With the knowledge of underlying platform, the prediction model could be shrunk, and the predicion process can be more efficient.
                Analysing the underlying principle of hardware platform is tough.
            
            
                Polynomial Model
                [10]NeuralPower[11]Predicting Execution Time  ...[12]Learning to Optimize Halide ...
                Contribute to more flexibility and low prediction error, model complexity can be adjusted by tunning the degree and term number of the polynomial.
                The term number and degree of polynomial should be designed elaborately, a model with too much terms will lead to low performance.
            
            
                Based on code detail
                [11]Predicting Execution Time  ...[12]Learning to Optimize Halide ...
                Using code features to assist prediction.
                The scalability is poor, because catching features from DNN algorithm is difficult, even some DNN frameworks are closed source.
            
            
                Layer-level prediction
                [1]Neurosurgeon[2]ÂµLayer[3]PALEO[8]CoDL[9]FBNet[12]NeuralPower
                Just need to predict the performance of one layer, the block-level prediction process is simplified.
                Because the lack of knowledge between operators, the block-level prediction accuracy is low.

                Take internal connection of block into consideration, achieving high block-level prediction accuracy.
                It is hard to catch the internal principle of operators in block.

Target(1) Accurate
Simple regression based on FLOPs is infeasible;
Some overhead in the inference process may be considered.
(2) Efficient
Blackbox neural network with high accuracy is complicated, leads to long delay in execution;
Take some hardware feature into consideration, but pay attention to the scalability.
(3) Block-level prediction
Summing up the predicted latency of each layer may give rise to accuracy loss, so layer-level latency prediction is not in the consideration;
Operator-level prediction based on operator fusion/ Graph embedding could be a choice.
System Design
To make sure the high accuracy of predictor, a general prediction model is trained, the hardware features like accelerator frequency, memory bandwidth  will be  embedded or considered as factors of model. Maybe the Random forest technique would be used to increase accuracy.
To achieve the light-weight characteristic,  I think one of the key contribution of this work could be fine tunning of layer-level predicted latency. In detail, many works have designed light-weight layer-level latency predictor, however their accuracy decrease when a block-level model is predicted, and it is really tough to design a block-level predictor considering accuracy and efficiency at the same time. To resolve above mentioned questions, we put ourselves in another shoes, just use the layer-level predictor, however the latency of each layer should be fine tuned through a little model, which takes hardware configurations into consideration. By the way, LASSO technique could be used to sparse features. 
For the scalability, the tunning model would be trained in the offline stage when deployed on a new platform.

Experiments1. Find the non-linear latency response as FLOPs increases1ï¼‰PC experiment
*Below Results are measured on a laptop equipped with a Nvidia RTX 3060 GPU & Intel 12th CORE i5 CPU.
Experimental subject: a Conv2D layer (input channel: 32), input a 13*13 data, the output channel is adjusted from 2 to 1024 in the process of experiment.
 
 


Fig.1 Latency response as FLOPs increases (by increasing number of output channel) on CPU


 


Fig.2 Latency response as FLOPs increases (by increasing number of output channel) on GPU

The results illustrate the non-linear latency response of  CNN layer, the phenomenon is clear in the CPU test. However, the result of test on GPU shows a staircase pattern in the beginning, the trend of latter part is different. The reason for this wired trend is the  influence of GPU frequency, more experiments will be done to figure out the mechanism of this phenomenon.
2) Embedded device experiment
*Below Results are measured on a Jetson NX development kit.
i. Latency response with different number of output channel




Fig.3 Latency response as FLOPs increases (by increasing number of output channel) on GPU





Fig.4 Latency response as FLOPs increases (by increasing number of output channel) on CPU

ii. Latency response with different input size




Fig.5 Latency response as FLOPs increases (by increasing number of input height) on GPU

2. Some interesting findings1) Sudden latency decrease when FLOPs increase




Fig.6 Sudden latency decrease under dynamic GPU frequency

From the experiment, I found that the frequency of GPU is dynamic for some reasons, which results in a couple of breakpoint in the FLOPs-Latency curve.
2) Inference latency performance with variable GPU frequency
Based on the phenomenon in the previous finding, I locked GPU frequency and measured inference latency with continuous output channel number under variable GPU frequency. We can find that the latency curve under different GPU almost follow the same pattern. 




Fig.7 Inference latency with continuous output channel number under variable GPU frequency

Further, I display the ratio of latency under different GPU frequency, and use 114.75MHz as basic frequency.




Fig.8 The ratio of latency under different GPU frequency

We can get some useful information from Fig.8. First, the latency ratio of two different GPU frequency convergence to a fixed value with the increase of FLOPs. More specifically, that fixed value approach to the reciprocal of frequency ratio with small deviation.
3) Inference latency related to output channel and input height
To analyze even further, I observed the relationship between computing FLOPs and inference latency. However, the step shape latency pattern shows no clear relationship with FLOPs. Nevertheless, I found some special laws in GPU inference. I measured a series of inference latency with continuous input height based on different latency.




Fig.9 Inference latency related to output channel and input height

We can figure out below findings:
i. The step pattern with input height has no relation with output channel, and the intervals between every two adjacent step levels are equal, which is 32 on test equipment.
ii. the latency curve has some sudden rise on typical output channel. Coincidentally, these special points are exactly the step points in Fig.7, which shows that the influence of input height and output channel are independent, and doesnâ€™t affect each other.
3.Layer-level latency predictor design



Fig.10 Inference latency related to output channel and input weight

As Fig.9 and Fig.10 illustrated, the $C_{out}$ deploys stepped latency curve when $C_{out}$ change on the latency pattern impacted by other parameters. So, I extract the influence of $C_{out}$ as a special term independent of other items. Next, I will deduce the special term in algebra.
We suppose the fundamental latency function without the influence of the special term as $f_0(x)$, the actual latency function $f_{co}^{p}(x)=(a_{co}+ns_{co})f_0(x)$, in where $a_{co}$ is the influence coefficient respects to the first step of $C_{out}$ pattern, $s_{co}$ is the step height of $C_{out}$ pattern. If we get all the above values, the actual function $f_{co}^{p}(x)$ can be determined, however, all the data we can measured has been influenced by the special term, we cannot capture $f_0(x)$ directly. Whatâ€™s more, the $C_{out}$ pattern is also influenced by other parameters, we cannot get $a_{co}$ and $s_{co}$ through measurement either. To deal with above difficulty, we can use the following method.
First, we can measure two latency curve with adjacent step numbers, denote as $[a_{co}+n_{co}s_{co}]f_0(x)$ and $[a_{co}+(n_{co}+1)s_{co}]f_0(x)$, and divide the two to get a convergent result $k_{co}$.
\frac{[a_{co}+(n_{co}+1)s_{co}]f_0(x)}{[a_{co}+n_{co}s_{co}]f_0(x)}\rightarrow k_{co}Through the derivation, we get $\frac{s_{co}}{a_{co}}=\frac{k_{co}-1}{1+n_{co}-n_{co}k_{co}}$,
The predicted latency under $C_{out}$ dimension is $f_{co}^{p}(x)=(a_{co}+ns_{co})f_0(x)=\frac{a_{co}+ns_{co}}{a_{co}+n_{co}s_{co}}(a_{co}+n_{co}s_{co})f_0(x)=\frac{1+n\frac{s_{co}}{a_{co}}}{1+n_{co}\frac{s_{co}}{a_{co}}}(a_{co}+n_{co}s_{co})f_0(x)$
$=\frac{1+\lceil\frac{C_o}{l_{co}}-1\rceil\frac{s_{co}}{a_{co}}}{1+n_{co}\frac{s_{co}}{a_{co}}}(a_{co}+n_{co}s_{co})f_0(x)$, ($l_{co}$ is the step length of $C_{out}$ pattern).
Therefore, we can get the latency patterns under distinct $C_{out}$ through multiplying the latency pattern under the measured curve $[a_{co}+n_{co}s_{co}]f_0(x)$ by a term $\frac{1+\lceil\frac{C_o}{l_{co}}-1\rceil\frac{s_{co}}{a_{co}}}{1+n_{co}\frac{s_{co}}{a_{co}}}$.




Fig.11 Inference latency related to input height and input channel






Fig.12 Inference latency related to input weight and input channel

As Fig.10 and Fig.11 illustrated, the same as the influence of $C_{out}$ on the other dimension of parameters, the input height and weight dimensions show step influence on the inference latency when the input channel changes. Therefore, we compress the four dimensions of latency curve ($\textit{i.e.}, C_{out}, H, W, C_{in}$) into the $C_{in}$ dimension. The specific process is as below.
We first measure four curves with GPU frequency $F_0$:
f{(C_i)}=(C_i ; H^{(n_H)},W^{(n_W)},C_o^{(n_{co})}),f_H{(C_i)}=(C_i ; H^{(n_H+1)},W^{(n_W)},C_o^{(n_{co})}),f_W{(C_i)}=(C_i ; H^{(n_H)},W^{(n_W+1)},C_o^{(n_{co})}),f_{co}{(C_i)}=(C_i ; H^{(n_H)},W^{(n_W)},C_o^{(n_{co}+1)}).The predicted latency curve under four dimensions is expressed as $f_p(H,W,C_o,C_i)=T_H(H)T_W(W)T_{C_o}(C_o)f(Ci)$.
Where,
$T_H(H)=\frac{1+\lceil\frac{H}{l_H}-1\rceil\frac{s_H}{a_H}}{1+n_H\frac{s_H}{a_H}}$, $\frac{s_H}{a_H}=\frac{k_H-1}{1+n_H-n_Hk_H}$, $k_H\rightarrow\frac{f_H(C_i)}{f(C_i)}$,
$T_W(W)=\frac{1+\lceil\frac{W}{l_W}-1\rceil\frac{s_W}{a_W}}{1+n_W\frac{s_W}{a_W}}$, $\frac{s_W}{a_W}=\frac{k_W-1}{1+n_W-n_Wk_W}$, $k_W\rightarrow\frac{f_W(C_i)}{f(C_i)}$,
$T_{C_o}(H)=\frac{1+\lceil\frac{C_o}{l_{C_o}}-1\rceil\frac{s_{C_o}}{a_{C_o}}}{1+n_{C_o}\frac{s_{C_o}}{a_{C_o}}}$, $\frac{s_{C_o}}{a_{C_o}}=\frac{k_{C_o}-1}{1+n_{C_o}-n_{C_o}k_{C_o}}$, $k_{C_o}\rightarrow\frac{f_{C_o}(C_i)}{f(C_i)}$.
Based on the finding in section 2-2), we add a special term to the predicted function, which reflects the influence of GPU frequency variation, as below:
f_{co}{(C_i)}=(C_i ; H^{(n_H)},W^{(n_W)},C_o^{(n_{co}+1)})\times F,F=\frac{F_0}{F_c}.$F_c$ is the current frequency of GPU.
4. Layer-level latency predictor evaluationWe evaluate the performance of the layer-level latency predictor preliminarily under two parameter settings.
The only priori data we have is four curves as below figure shows.




Fig.13 Priori data of four curves

The comparison  between the predicted latency curve and real measured latency curve under two parameter settings is as below.




Fig.14 Prediction performance evaluation (H=92, W=68, Co=72) [Avg Error: 4.6%]





Fig.15 Prediction performance evaluation (H=48, W=80, Co=160) [Avg Error: 7.5%]





Fig.16 Layer-level latency prediction under variable GPU frequency [Avg Error: 12.5%]


5. Operator fusion1) PyTorch
Below experiment is set to explore the optimization when execute some specific operators in sequence, in which the operator fusion is the most vital one. This experiment is executed on PyTorch framework and measured inference latency of 1) single Conv operator, 2) single bn operator, 3) Conv+bn in sequence under variable output channels, and the sum of 1) and 2) is calculated in compare with latency of 3). 




Fig.17 Difference of connected and separated operators < conv+bn > in PyTorch

From the result, we can find that 3) consumes less latency than sum of 1) and 2), which maybe caused by the framework optimization.
Further more, a series of experiments on different combination of operators to figure out  whether the operator fusion optimization exist when processing DNN models based on deep learning framework, e.g., PyTorch in this experiment.




Fig.18 Difference of connected and separated operators < conv+bn+relu >  in PyTorch





Fig.19 Difference of connected and separated operators < bn+conv >  in PyTorch





Fig.20 Difference of connected and separated operators < conv+relu >  in PyTorch





Fig.21 Difference of connected and separated operators < pool+bn >  in PyTorch

The average latency reduction ratio of connected and separated operators is recorded in below table.
Table3. The average latency reduction ratio of connected and separated operators





However, when increasing the computation, we get below experiment results.




Fig.22 Difference of connected and separated operators < pool+bn >  in PyTorch (high computation)





Fig.23 Difference of connected and separated operators < conv+bn >  in PyTorch (high computation)

Table4. The average latency reduction ratio of connected and separated operators





When the computation increase, the latency reduction ratio of connected operators decrease sharply. This phenomenon shows that the PyTorch framework may not do operator fusion optimization for operators, and the optimization performance could caused by other optimization techniques or error in measurement.
2) TensorRT
In this part, we explore the operator fusion optimization performance in TensorRT, which is a model inference acceleration framework produced by NVIDIA. All the operators are packed into model and processed by a TensorRT engine to a TensorRT model, below figures illustrate the latency performance difference of connected operators and separate operators.




Fig.24 Difference of connected and separated operators < conv+bn >  in TensorRT





Fig.25 Difference of connected and separated operators < conv+relu >  in TensorRT





Fig.26 Difference of connected and separated operators < conv+pool >  in TensorRT





Fig.27 Difference of connected and separated operators < conv+conv >  in TensorRT





Fig.28 Difference of connected and separated operators < bn+add >  in TensorRT

Table5. The average latency reduction ratio of connected and separated operators





Through the above results, we can reach a conclusion that, TensorRT do employs operator fusion optimization to some kinds of operators. The difference between connected and separated operators  when operator fusion happens is much higher than PyTorch, which doesnâ€™t do operator fusion optimization for operators.

class Net(nn.Module):    """    ä½¿ç”¨sequentialæ„å»ºç½‘ç»œï¼ŒSequential()å‡½æ•°çš„åŠŸèƒ½æ˜¯å°†ç½‘ç»œçš„å±‚ç»„åˆåˆ°ä¸€èµ·    """    def __init__(self, in_dim, n_hidden_1, n_hidden_2, out_dim):        super(Net, self).__init__()        self.layer1 = nn.Sequential(nn.Linear(in_dim, n_hidden_1),nn.BatchNorm1d(n_hidden_1))        self.layer2 = nn.Sequential(nn.Linear(n_hidden_1, n_hidden_2),nn.BatchNorm1d (n_hidden_2))        self.layer3 = nn.Sequential(nn.Linear(n_hidden_2, out_dim))    def forward(self, x):        x = F.relu(self.layer1(x))        x = F.relu(self.layer2(x))        x = self.layer3(x)        return x

# å¼€å§‹è®­ç»ƒlosses = []acces = []eval_losses = []eval_acces = []for epoch in range(num_epoches):    train_loss = 0    train_acc = 0    #å°†moduleè®¾ç½®ä¸ºè®­ç»ƒæ¨¡å¼    model.train()	#åŠ¨æ€ä¿®æ”¹å‚æ•°å­¦ä¹ ç‡    if epoch%5==0:        optimizer.param_groups[0]['lr']*=0.1    for img, label in train_loader:        img=img.to(device)        label = label.to(device)        img = img.view(img.size(0), -1)        # å‰å‘ä¼ æ’­        out = model(img)        loss = criterion(out, label)        # åå‘ä¼ æ’­        optimizer.zero_grad()        loss.backward()        optimizer.step()        # è®°å½•è¯¯å·®        train_loss += loss.item()        # è®¡ç®—åˆ†ç±»çš„å‡†ç¡®ç‡        _, pred = out.max(1)        num_correct = (pred == label).sum().item()        acc = num_correct / img.shape[0]        train_acc += acc    losses.append(train_loss / len(train_loader))    acces.append(train_acc / len(train_loader))    # åœ¨æµ‹è¯•é›†ä¸Šæ£€éªŒæ•ˆæœ    eval_loss = 0    eval_acc = 0	# å°†æ¨¡å‹æ”¹ä¸ºé¢„æµ‹æ¨¡å¼ï¼ˆä¼šå°†æ‰€æœ‰çš„trainingå±æ€§è®¾ç½®ä¸ºFalseï¼‰    model.eval()    for img, label in test_loader:        img=img.to(device)        label = label.to(device)        img = img.view(img.size(0), -1)        out = model(img)        loss = criterion(out, label)        # è®°å½•è¯¯å·®        eval_loss += loss.item()        # è®°å½•å‡†ç¡®ç‡        _, pred = out.max(1)        num_correct = (pred == label).sum().item()        acc = num_correct / img.shape[0]        eval_acc += acc    eval_losses.append(eval_loss / len(test_loader))    eval_acces.append(eval_acc / len(test_loader))    print('epoch: {}, Train Loss: {:.4f}, Train Acc: {:.4f}, Test Loss: {:.4f}, Test Acc: {:.4f}'          .format(epoch, train_loss / len(train_loader), train_acc / len(train_loader),                      eval_loss / len(test_loader), eval_acc / len(test_loader)))
